title: 108_s1625
content: The "Apprenticeship, Training, and Employment Act of 2003" allows for a tax credit for expenses related to long-term training of employees in highly skilled small business trades. The "Apprenticeship, Training, and Employment Act of 2003" provides a tax credit of $10,000 per employee for small business employers in highly skilled trades training, with a maximum of 3 employees eligible. Small business employers are defined as specialty trade contractors in sector 23. The "Apprenticeship, Training, and Employment Act of 2003" offers a $10,000 tax credit per employee for small business employers in highly skilled trades training. A qualified training year requires an employee to receive at least 1,500 hours of training in a highly skilled trade. The term 'highly skilled trades' refers to specialty trades with a customary apprenticeship period of at least 2 years. A 'qualified training program' is a written plan for individuals in highly skilled trades. A plan for a qualified training program in highly skilled trades must meet specific requirements and be either a registered apprenticeship program under the National Apprenticeship Act or a program licensed, registered, or certified by the workforce investment board or apprenticeship agency of a State. A qualified training program in highly skilled trades must meet specific requirements, including accessibility without discrimination and providing comprehensive trade instruction. A qualified training program in highly skilled trades must provide training in math, measurement, blueprint reading, trade-specific tools and equipment, safety and health, on-the-job training under supervision, and periodic evaluation of participants. The training period for an employee in a highly skilled trade begins on the employment start date and ends either when the apprenticeship ends or 2 years after the start date. The amount of credit allowable under sections 51(a) and 1396(a) for an employee is reduced by the credit allowed under this section. The highly skilled trades training credit for small business employers is included in the general business credit. No deduction is allowed for training expenses for employees in highly skilled small business trades. No deduction allowed for expenses equal to the credit determined under section 45G(a) for small business trades. Clerical amendment made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to expenses for long-term training of employees in highly skilled small business trades, incurred in taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act.
